data.title: Hong Kong Appoints Chair and Members for Stablecoin Review Tribunal
data.description: According to Odaily, the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region has appointed the chair and members of the Stablecoin Review Tribunal under the Stablecoin Ordinance (Chapter 656). Senior barrister Lan De Ye will serve as the chair, with panel members including Professor Huang Hao, Qiu Yuan Yun, Lu Zhi Hong, Mai Ye Cheng, Wu Jian Lin, and Xiao Zi Qian. The tribunal, established under the Stablecoin Ordinance, is tasked with reviewing specified decisions made by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority upon receiving appeals. This initiative aims to ensure that regulatory decisions are reasonable and fair.

data.title: Yi Lihua: I started buying ETH when it dropped to $1800 and sold it all around $4500.
data.description: Liquid Capital founder Yi Lihua posted on the X platform: "Many people ask why our bottom-fishing and top-selling strategies are relatively accurate. The truth is, it's not as rosy as it seems. When ETH fell to $1800, we started buying. We panicked when it dropped to $1350. Later, we started calling for buying when it rebounded to $1450 and issued research reports at $1750. When it reached $2700, the Middle East black swan event caused a pullback to $2100, which led to us being ridiculed online as 'E Lihua.' Then, we prematurely unleveraged at over $3000 and liquidated our positions around $4500 instead of $4900. No one is 100% correct, but in the right trend, fatal mistakes are less likely. Buying is for selling, and selling is for buying."

data.title: This week's top mining news highlights: Riot reports $104.5 million net profit in the third quarter.
data.description: Week 43 of 2025 (October 24 - October 30): 1. According to blockchain.com, the average price of Bitcoin was $112,055, with a high of $116,410 and a low of $106,279, up 3.59% from the average price of the previous week ($108,171). 2. Mining news worth noting includes: (1) Riot's net profit in the third quarter was US$104.5 million, a record revenue that reversed the previous quarter's loss; (2) Phoenix Group released its Q3 quarterly report: holding 682 BTC and 642,000 SOL; (3) Canaan Technology announced that it has signed a 4.5MW contract in Japan to deploy its Avalon water-cooled Bitcoin mining machines; (4) Bitdeer's Bitcoin holdings exceeded 2,180, and it mined 123.4 BTC last week; Data partner: Cango Inc. (CANG), a Bitcoin mining company listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

data.title: Bitcoin Spot ETFs Experience Significant Outflows
data.description:
According to PANews, data from SoSoValue indicates that on October 30, Bitcoin spot ETFs saw a total net outflow of $488 million. The largest single-day net outflow was recorded by BlackRock's ETF IBIT, which experienced a withdrawal of $291 million. Despite this, IBIT's historical total net inflow stands at $65.052 billion.

Following IBIT, the ETF ARKB, managed by Ark Invest and 21Shares, reported a net outflow of $65.6193 million. The historical total net inflow for ARKB is currently $2.053 billion.

As of the latest report, the total net asset value of Bitcoin spot ETFs is $143.944 billion, with an ETF net asset ratio of 6.71% relative to Bitcoin's total market capitalization. The cumulative historical net inflow for these ETFs has reached $61.378 billion.

data.title: Bitcoin spot ETFs saw a total net outflow of $488 million yesterday, with none of the twelve ETFs experiencing net inflows.
data.description: According to SoSoValue data, Bitcoin spot ETFs saw a total net outflow of $488 million yesterday (October 30th, Eastern Time). The BlackRock ETF IBIT experienced the largest single-day net outflow, at $291 million, bringing its historical total net inflow to $65.052 billion. Following closely was the Ark Invest and 21Shares ETF ARKB, with a single-day net outflow of $65.6193 million, bringing its historical total net inflow to $2.053 billion. As of this writing, the total net asset value of Bitcoin spot ETFs is $143.944 billion, with an ETF net asset value ratio (market capitalization as a percentage of total Bitcoin market capitalization) of 6.71%, and a historical cumulative net inflow of $61.378 billion.

data.title: EXCLUSIVE: Top Crypto CEO Backs Cathie Wood's $1 Million Target For Bitcoin, Here's How Long It's Going To Take
data.description:
A top crypto boss is on board with Ark Invest's Cathie Wood's bold call that Bitcoin could eventually hit $1 million — just not anytime soon. 
source: https://www.benzinga.com/crypto/cryptocurrency/25/10/48549668/exclusive-top-crypto-ceo-backs-cathie-woods-1-million-target-for-bitcoin-heres-how-long-its-going-to-take?utm_source=cryptopanic.com&utm_campaign=partner_feed&utm_medium=partner_feed&utm_content=site

data.title: A New York court extended an asset freeze order to assist with the liquidation of Multichain in Singapore.
data.description: On Thursday, a New York judge temporarily extended a freeze order on wallets holding approximately $63 million worth of stolen USDC stablecoins, supporting a request from the liquidators of the defunct cryptocurrency cross-chain bridge Multichain in Singapore. Judge David S. Jones ordered Circle to keep three Ethereum wallets frozen and to retain the dollar reserves backing the stolen USDC. The liquidators warned that lifting the freeze order in the state court would cause “irreparable harm.” The order also suspended another class-action lawsuit filed by a group of U.S. investors attempting to gain control of the funds. The case was transferred to the Southern District of New York federal court last Friday after Circle invoked the Fair Class Action Act. Under Section 1519 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, the order is temporary, and the court will review whether the Singapore liquidation proceedings meet the criteria for “foreign principal proceedings” to regulate cross-border bankruptcy cooperation. (Decrypt)

data.title: Potential December Rate Hike by Bank of Japan Analyzed
data.description:
According to BlockBeats, DBS Bank analyst Ma Tieying has commented on the possibility of the Bank of Japan raising its policy rate by 25 basis points in December.

The senior economist anticipates that Japanese labor unions will set their wage negotiation targets for 2026 around November to December. She noted that the Japanese Trade Union Confederation has already indicated a wage growth target of 5% for 2026, consistent with this year's target.

Furthermore, the economist mentioned that if the Federal Reserve delays its rate cut during the December meeting, the likelihood of a rate hike by the Bank of Japan in December could increase, providing a window of opportunity for action.

data.title: New York Judge Extends Freeze on Stolen USDC Wallets
data.description:
According to Odaily, a New York judge has temporarily extended the freeze on wallets holding approximately $63 million in stolen USDC stablecoins. This decision supports the request of the liquidator from the now-defunct cryptocurrency cross-chain bridge, Multichain, based in Singapore.

Judge David S. Jones has ordered Circle to maintain the freeze on three Ethereum wallets and preserve the dollar reserves backing the stolen USDC. The liquidator warned that lifting the freeze could result in 'irreparable harm.' Additionally, the order has paused a separate class-action lawsuit initiated by a group of U.S. investors seeking control over the funds.

Last Friday, the case was transferred to the federal court in the Southern District of New York after Circle invoked the Class Action Fairness Act. Under Section 1519 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, the order is temporary, and the court will review whether the Singapore liquidation process qualifies as a 'foreign main proceeding' to regulate cross-border bankruptcy cooperation.

data.title: The SBF account posted again: FTX never truly went bankrupt; what happened back then was essentially a liquidity crisis.
data.description: The SBF account posted an image today of an article titled "FTX: Where Did The Money Go?", authored by SBF himself and his team, and last updated on September 30, 2025. The article outlines FTX's payouts in recent years and emphasizes that FTX's crisis in November 2022 was essentially a liquidity crisis, i.e., a temporary shortage of funds. The problem was originally expected to be resolved by the end of the month—until FTX's outside lawyers took over the company. FTX never truly went bankrupt, not even when its lawyers pushed it into bankruptcy proceedings.

data.title: After being liquidated, Brother Machi continued to increase his long positions in ETH, resulting in a total loss of $14.5 million.
data.description: According to Onchain Lens monitoring, after being liquidated, Machi continued to increase his ETH long position with 25x leverage, and his losses in contract and spot trading have now reached $14.5 million.
